response:
Among the socioeconomic classes, in terms of a person who commutes to work or school, my final answer is: upper-class.

According to the U.S. Census Bureau, in 2019, 77.1% of households in the upper-class category had at least one person who commuted to work or school, compared to 64.7% of households in the middle-class category, 57.4% of households in the upper-middle-class category, and 44.5% of households in the lower-middle-class category.

It's worth noting that these statistics are based on a broad definition of the socioeconomic classes, and there may be variations within each category depending on factors such as location, occupation, and other factors. However, based on the available data, it appears that the upper-class category has the highest percentage of people who commute to work or school.
